Introduction

Roseola infantum (exanthema subitum or sixth disease) is a common childhood viral exanthem caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6).  It presents with a high fever for several days, followed by abrupt defervescence and the development of a maculopapular rash.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



HHV-6 infects most children by age 2 years and is most likely transmitted through infected secretions of asymptomatic close contacts (eg, via saliva from mother to infant).  Following transmission, the mean incubation period is approximately 9-10 days.  HHV-6 replicates within CD4+ T cells, causing immune dysfunction and cytokine production that manifests as high fever.  The cause of the rash is unknown but may be related to antibody-antigen interaction after the initial febrile phase.



After initial infection, HHV-6 remains latent in the body, contributing to asymptomatic lifelong shedding and a high prevalence of infection among infants and young children with no known exposure.  There are no risk factors for roseola infantum, but infection is most common in children age <2.

Clinical presentation



Classic roseola (

figure 1
) presents in children age <2 with 3-5 days of high fevers (eg, >40 C [104 F]).  Despite the fever, patients are usually well-appearing.  Other nonspecific viral symptoms may be present (eg, rhinorrhea, cervical lymphadenopathy, diarrhea), and the risk for febrile seizures is increased during the febrile phase.



Following the abrupt resolution of fever, a rash (

image 1
) develops and is characterized by blanching, nonpruritic, rose-colored macules and/or papules.  It begins on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities.  The rash self-resolves within 1-2 days.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of roseola is based on the clinical presentation of high fever for 3-5 days in a young child, followed by defervescence and development of the characteristic rash.



Laboratory tests are not typically necessary for diagnosis but may be obtained when evaluating an unexplained fever.  In these cases, laboratory evaluation may show nonspecific neutropenia and thrombocytopenia from transient bone marrow suppression, as well as sterile pyuria.  Confirmation of HHV-6 infection can be obtained in atypical presentations or immunocompromised patients.

Differential diagnosis



Other erythematous childhood rashes may appear similar to roseola, including the following:



  • Rubella:  typically presents with a maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities.  Rubella is also often associated with posterior auricular and occipital lymphadenopathy.

  • Measles:  typically presents with a maculopapular rash on the face that spreads to the trunk and extremities.  In addition, measles is characterized by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and pathognomonic Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa.

  • Scarlet fever:  typically presents as a sandpaper-like rash (

    image 2
    ) that starts in the axillae or groin and spreads to the trunk and extremities.  Patients may also have pharyngitis and fever.

  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:  often presents with oral vesicles (

    image 3
    ) and maculopapular (
    image 4
    ) or vesicular lesions on the palms and soles.

  • Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease):  commonly presents with a rash after fever onset.  In contrast to roseola, the rash from erythema infectiosum begins on the face with a slapped-cheek (

    image 5
    ) appearance (malar rash) followed by a reticulated truncal rash (
    image 6
    ).

  • Primary varicella-zoster infection (chickenpox):  presents with a prodrome of fever and malaise followed by diffuse crops of rashes.  Chickenpox is characterized by a diffuse pruritic and vesicular rash in different stages of development on the face, trunk, and extremities.

Management



Management of roseola is supportive and focuses on alleviating symptoms such as fever and discomfort (eg, antipyretic medications, hydration).  The infection is typically benign and self-limited.  Caretakers should be reassured that the rash is not contagious and does not require treatment.

Complications



Roseola is usually a self-limited disease.  During the febrile phase, a small percentage of patients with HHV-6 infection may develop febrile seizures that resolve without complications.  Treatment of these patients is with reassurance and supportive care.

Summary
